summary: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a type of chronic leukemia where the bone marrow makes abnormal lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). These abnormal cells crowd out healthy cells, leading to infection, anemia, and easy bleeding. The abnormal cells can also spread outside the blood to other parts of the body. CLL usually gets worse slowly and is one of the most common types of leukemia in adults, often occurring during or after middle age.
causes: Changes in the genetic material (DNA) in bone marrow cells
risk_factors: Family history of CLL and other blood and bone marrow diseases
Exposure to certain chemicals, including Agent Orange
symptoms: Pain or fullness below the ribs
diagnosis: Blood tests (complete blood count with differential, blood chemistry tests)
treatments: Chemotherapy with bone marrow or stem cell transplant
